awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for US researchers to attend a conference entitled "Complex Analysis and Geometry" in Budapest, Hungary. The conference will take place in June 23-30,2023, and will be hosted by the Alfréd Rényi Institute of Mathematics. The topics of the conference emphasize the rich interactions between complex analysis and complex geometry. The conference will bring together well-known experts and junior researchers with the aim of communicating recent progress in the field and fostering research interaction and collaboration. Funds from the NSF will be used to support US participation in the conference.  Applications from early career mathematicians and underrepresented groups will be particularly encouraged. 

Key topics in this conference will include potential theoretic methods for the PDE's of complex geometry, potential theoretic methods in complex algebraic geometry and the Bergman kernel, complex dynamics in several variables, Oka manifolds and more. A conference focusing on these topics is timely considering the many recent exciting developments in these areas. The conference website is https://conferences.renyi.hu/lempert70/home

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This conference was devoted to recent trends in complex analysis and complex geometry. Topics of interest included PDEs in complex geometry, potential theoretical methods in complex and non-Archimedean geometry, complex dynamics in SCV, and Andersén-Lempert theory.

The conference featured 18 plenary talks delivered by experts in the field. More specifically, Sébastien Boucksom spoke about measures of finite energy in complex and non-Archimedean pluripotential theory, Duong H. Phong discussed Diameters and Green's functions in Kähler geometry, Gábor Székelyhidi addressed Regularity for singular Kähler-Einstein metric, Jasmin Raissy covered spiralling domains in dimension 2, Andrew Zimmer presented a metric analogue of Hartogs's theorem, and Mei-Chi Shaw discussed the Cauchy-Riemann equations on the Hartogs triangles. We had many other great talks and the conference also served as an opportunity to celebrate the accomplishments of László Lempert on the occasion of his 70th birthday.

There were nearly 70 participants, including many students, postdocs, and representatives from underrepresented groups. Every effort was made to attract as many underrepresented participants as possible, with support from the NSF proving very helpful in this regard.

One of the primary goals of the grant was to foster collaboration between researchers in the USA and abroad, particularly in Eastern/Central Europe. The Rényi Institute in Budapest served as an excellent host, contributing to the success of the meeting. Furthermore, most of the conference talks were recorded and are now publicly available on both the video archive of the Rényi Institute and the conference website (https://conferences.renyi.hu/lempert70/), serving as a lasting record of our activities.

Most of the funding was allocated to supporting the participation of students and early career mathematicians from the US, who lacked other means of support. We had two afternoon short talk sessions dedicated to junior participants. As a result, graduate students and early-stage researchers had the opportunity to interact with leading experts in the field and receive much needed feedback on their work.

 


Last Modified: 05/10/2024
Modified by: Tamas Darvas
